ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Misophonia
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Specific triggers (chewing, sniffling) cause immediate autonomic arousal (fight/flight) and anger; hearing is normal; LDLs > 90 dB HL rule out hyperacusis.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Previously diagnosed due to 'ruminating' on sounds and perfectionism, but symptoms are driven by external auditory stimuli rather than internal intrusive thoughts.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Hyperacusis
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Considered due to sound sensitivity, but ruled out as Loudness Discomfort Levels exceeded 90 dB HL.

ordered_list.rationale_short: Assess hearing sensitivity to rule out hearing loss.
Evaluate sound tolerance limits to distinguish between misophonia and hyperacusis.
Assessment of psychological impact and identification of specific triggers.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Diagnostic testing revealed normal hearing sensitivity and middle ear function. OAEs were robust. Loudness Discomfort Levels > 90 dB HL ruled out loudness hyperacusis. The profile of specific trigger-based reactions without physical pain or general loudness intolerance is consistent with misophonia.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Word recognition in quiet was excellent.

tests.name: Otoacoustic emissions (OAEs)
tests.result_summary: Present from 0.750 to 10 kHz bilaterally, suggesting normal outer hair cell function.

tests.name: Loudness Discomfort Levels
tests.result_summary: Tolerance of signals in excess of 90 dB HL contraindicates presence of loudness hyperacusis.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Initial session of the coping skills program focused on history and psychological impact. The patient reported feeling 'cursed' and identified specific triggers (father, teacher) and emotional responses (anger, feeling like a monster).

tests.name: Other
tests.result_summary: Assessment of psychological impact: Patient felt 'cursed' and feared triggers were spreading. Identified specific triggers (father, teacher).

counseling_actions: Psychoeducation regarding misophonia as a neurological/auditory disorder rather than a psychiatric one
Explanation of the fight/flight response mechanism
Debunking misinformation found on the internet
Cognitive reframing to separate the sound from the person
Advice to family to allow the patient to eat separately or take breaks until coping skills are developed

escalation.rationale_short: Patient requires a specialized 10-week coping skills program managed by the audiologist.

follow_up_plan.objective: Complete 10 sessions of coping skills training to manage physiological arousal and improve quality of life.

expected_outcome: Patient demonstrated a much clearer understanding of misophonia and how it influenced her daily activities physiologically, cognitively, and emotionally.
Patient was able to separate the idea that people were triggers and understood that sounds were the issue.
Patient successfully utilized athletic abilities (light weights), four-square breathing, and hand grippers to manage arousal levels and return to homeostasis.
Patient utilized ear-level sound generators to mask sounds.
Activity level, interaction with family members, confidence in managing the condition, and reported sense of greater tolerance to potentially triggering sounds improved substantially.
